id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: While most health-related indicators are moving in the right direction globally, current trends are insufficient to meet targets set for 2030.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The maternal mortality ratio is largely stuck at a level more than three times the 2030 target.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Without accelerated declines, 35 million children will not live to see their fifth birthday by 2030.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Inequalities and emerging threats jeopardize these accomplishments, however, underscoring the need for sustained efforts and innovative strategies.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The world is not on track to achieve Goal 3.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Changing course requires prioritizing the achievement of universal health coverage, strengthening health systems, investing in disease prevention and treatment, and addressing disparities in access to care and services, especially for vulnerable populations.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: COVID-19 swiftly reversed this positive trend, with global life expectancy plummeting to 71.4 years by 2021, back to the level of 2012.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Before the pandemic, non-communicable diseases had been steadily increasing as the leading cause of death, accounting for 59.5 per cent of all deaths in 2000 and 73.9 per cent in 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The share of communicable diseases dropped from 32.2 per cent in 2000 to 18.2 per cent in 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: As COVID-19 emerged as a new infectious disease and started to take a toll on human lives, the share of deaths due to communicable diseases jumped back to the 2005 level (28.1 per cent) in 2021, while the share of deaths due to non-communicable diseases decreased to 65.3 per cent.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: COVID-19 ranked among the top three leading causes of death globally in 2020 and 2021, with striking regional variations.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Progress towards universal health coverage has slowed, leaving billions without care and subject to catastrophic costs.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Essential health service coverage is measured using an index, reported on a score of 0 to 100, based on 14 indicators across four domains: reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health; infectious diseases; non-communicable diseases; and service capacity and access.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The global score on the index increased remarkably from 45 in 2000 to 65 in 2015.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Progress slowed thereafter, however, reaching a score of only 68 in 2021.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The proportion of the population lacking essential health services fell by approximately 15 per cent between 2000 and 2021.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Yet minimal progress after 2015 left about 4.5 billion people without coverage in 2021, especially in rural and poorer populations.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Financial hardship due to out-of-pocket health spending has worsened since 2015, affecting 2 billion people in 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: They included 1 billion people facing catastrophic health expenditures exceeding 10 per cent of their household budget and 344 million driven deeper into extreme poverty by health costs.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The proportion of the population with catastrophic expenditures increased from 12.6 per cent in 2015 to 13.5 per cent in 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Progressing towards universal health coverage requires addressing the global shortage of health workers.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Yet data from 2015 to 2022 reveal stark disparities, with low-income countries experiencing the lowest health worker density and distribution.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Per 10,000 people, these countries had medians of only 1.1 medical doctors, 7.5 nursing and midwifery personnel, 0.04 dentists and 0.2 pharmacists, compared with medians in high-income countries of 35.6 medical doctors, 76.8 nursing and midwifery personnel, 7.0 dentists and 8.8 pharmacists.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Health systems are experiencing increased strains in catering to the mounting health needs of an ageing global population, more so because the health workforce itself is ageing.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: An estimated 1.8 million additional health workers are needed in 54 countries, primarily high-income ones, to replace retiring health professionals and maintain the current age-standardized density of health workers.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Declines in maternal mortality have stalled, with wide disparities by region and income.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Between 2015 and 2020, the global maternal mortality ratio declined only marginally from 227 to 223 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, over three times higher than the 2030 target of 70.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Sub-Saharan Africa and Southern Asia account for 87 per cent of maternal deaths.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The average maternal mortality ratio for very high and high alert fragile states was 551 in 2020, more than twice the global average.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Achieving the 2030 target requires an annual reduction rate of 11.6 per cent between 2021 and 2030.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Skilled birth attendance has improved globally, rising from 80 per cent of births in 2015 to 86 per cent in 2023.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Improved care quality could save the lives of up to 1 million newborns and 150,000 mothers annually.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Yet progress is stalling; 18 million births occurred without skilled assistance in 2023.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In sub-Saharan Africa, only 73 per cent of births were attended by skilled personnel in 2023, the lowest rate worldwide.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In contrast, Eastern and South-Eastern Asia achieved a rate of 96 per cent.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Improvements in adolescent birth rates and access to modern contraceptives do not benefit all women and girls equally.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The adolescent birth rate for women aged 15–19 years declined to 41.3 births per 1,000 women in 2023, from 47.2 in 2015 and 64.5 in 2000.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: For girls aged 10–14 years, the rate fell from 3.3 births per 1,000 girls in 2000 to 1.8 in 2015 and 1.5 in 2023.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Yet 13.1 million babies, approximately 10 per cent of the total number of births, were born to adolescent mothers in 2023.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Central and Southern Asia witnessed the largest drop-offs in adolescent birth rates between 2000 and 2023, with a 72 per cent reduction in the 15–19 age group and a 90 per cent decrease in the 10–14 cohort.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Sub-Saharan Africa continued to have the highest rates globally, at 97.9 births per 1,000 women aged 15–19 and 4.4 per 1,000 girls aged 10–14 in 2023.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The proportion of women of reproductive age (15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods has climbed from 76.5 per cent in 2015 to 77.6 per cent in 2024.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: By 2030, this proportion is projected to reach 78.2 per cent, a net increase of 45 million women.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: This marks a fair improvement but still falls far short of universal access.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Global under-5 deaths reached a historic low of 4.9 million in 2022, down from 9.9 million in 2000 and 6.0 million in 2015.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Nearly half these deaths (2.3 million) occurred during the neonatal period (the first 28 days of life).

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Unfortunately, the annual rate of reduction in under-5 mortality contracted from 3.8 per cent in 2000–2015 to 2.1 per cent in 2015–2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The neonatal mortality rate followed a similar pattern, declining from 3.0 per cent to 1.8 per cent.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: As of 2022, 134 countries had already met the target.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Seven more were on track but 59 countries, nearly three quarters of which are in sub-Saharan Africa, will need faster progress to meet the target.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Efforts to combat communicable diseases have prevented millions of deaths but are threatened by inequalities and emerging threats.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The world has made significant strides in combating HIV.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, an estimated 1.3 million new infections represented a 27 per cent decrease since 2015 and a 38 per cent reduction since 2010.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Sub-Saharan Africa, the region most affected by HIV, has more than halved new infections annually since 2010.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, 29.8 million of the 39 million people living with HIV were receiving life-saving treatment.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Increased access to treatment has averted 20.8 million AIDS-related deaths in the past three decades.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In addition, the integration of HIV testing and treatment with maternal and childcare services has prevented over 3.4 million HIV infections in children since 2000.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Stronger linking of services for HIV and tuberculosis has averted an estimated 6.4 million tuberculosis-related deaths among people living with HIV from 2010 to 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Not everyone is benefiting equally from these advancements, however.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, 43 per cent of the 1.5 million children living with HIV were not receiving treatment.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Every week, 4,000 adolescent girls and young women acquired HIV; 3,100 lived in sub-Saharan Africa.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Almost a quarter of new HIV infections were in Asia in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Steep increases of new HIV infections have continued in Northern Africa and Western Asia.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: These worrying trends are primarily due to a lack of preventive services for people from marginalized and key populations, punitive laws, violence, social stigma and discrimination.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The reported number of people newly diagnosed with tuberculosis reached 7.5 million in 2022, the highest figure since global monitoring began in 1995 and above the previous historical peak of 7.1 million in 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Worldwide, an estimated 10.6 million people developed tuberculosis in 2022, up from 10.3 million in 2021 and 10.0 million in 2020.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The disease remains the world’s second leading cause of death from a single infectious agent, with an estimated 1.3 million deaths in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: This was down from the estimated 1.4 million deaths in both 2020 and 2021 and almost back to pre-pandemic levels.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The global net decrease in tuberculosis-related deaths between 2015 and 2022, however, was 19 per cent, well below the target of a 75 per cent reduction by 2025.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: An estimated 249 million malaria cases occurred globally in 2022, 16 million more than in 2019 before the pandemic.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The disease claimed an estimated 608,000 lives in 2022, an increase of 32,000 compared to 2019.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Since 2015, insecticide-treated net use among young children and pregnant women in sub-Saharan Africa has stagnated at around 56 per cent.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, an estimated 58 per cent of at-risk pregnant women did not receive the recommended preventive malaria therapy, and about one third of children with fever did not receive care from a health provider.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Alongside disruptions caused by COVID-19, the global malaria response faces increasing threats, including drug and insecticide resistance, humanitarian crises, funding constraints, delays in programme implementation and climate change impacts.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Despite these challenges, some important achievements sustain progress towards elimination in many countries with a low malaria burden, with 25 countries reporting fewer than 10 cases in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Thirteen countries have been certified malaria-free since 2015.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, 1.6 billion people required treatment and care for neglected tropical diseases, a 26.1 per cent decline from 2010.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: The proportion of the population living in LDCs who required interventions for these diseases decreased from 79 per cent to 45 per cent during this period.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: As of December 2023, 50 countries, territories and areas had eliminated at least one neglected tropical disease, demonstrating the power of comprehensive interventions combining mass and individual treatment, vector control, veterinary public health and provision of safe water and sanitation.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Progress has not been fast enough to meet the target of reducing the global population requiring interventions for neglected tropical diseases by 90 per cent between 2010 and 2030.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Achieving this target demands a renewed effort to scale up interventions, particularly in high-burden countries, many of which are LDCs.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Twenty-one million children missed out on life-saving vaccines in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Between 2000 and 2019, the proportion of children receiving three doses of the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis (DTP3) vaccine rose from 72 to 86 per cent, then dipped to 81 per cent in 2021 before rebounding to 84 per cent in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, 20.5 million children missed at least one routine vaccine and 14.3 million received no vaccines at all.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Coverage of two doses of the measles vaccine and three doses of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine increased in 2022, reaching 74 per cent and 60 per cent, respectively, following stagnation in 2020–2021.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Global coverage of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine, critical for women’s and girls’ health, stood at only 15 per cent in 2022, despite 130 countries introducing it in their national immunization services by the end of the year.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Treatment reaches only marginal shares of people with drug and alcohol disorders.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Newly available estimates reveal that globally, only about 1 in 11 individuals with drug use disorders received related treatment in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Coverage decreased from 11 per cent to under 9 per cent between 2015 and 2022, and has notably decelerated in the Americas and Asia.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Treatment coverage for women consistently lags behind that for men across all regions, with over 13 per cent of men receiving treatment compared to less than 6 per cent of women in 2022.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Data on access to treatment for those with alcohol use disorders indicate a dire situation, with coverage ranging from 0.3 per cent to a maximum of 14 per cent in reporting countries.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Considering that approximately 283 million people or 5 per cent of the adult population lives with alcohol use disorders, hundreds of millions are going without needed treatment and care.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: More than 9 in 10 deaths caused by air pollution occur in lower- and middle-income countries.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Particulate air pollution caused approximately 104 deaths per 100,000 people annually by 2019, despite a slight decrease in the global mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution since 2010.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Ninety-three per cent of the burden fell on low- and middle-income countries in 2019, primarily in Asia and Africa.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Non-communicable diseases accounted for 85 per cent of air pollution-related deaths, while acute lower respiratory infections made up the remaining 15 per cent.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Concerningly, 31 per cent of deaths from acute lower respiratory infections occurred in children under age 5.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Oceania (excluding Australia and New Zealand), sub-Saharan Africa and most of Asia have the highest mortality rates attributable to air pollution.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: This is largely due to significant exposure to air pollution in households, a large proportion of which rely on polluting fuels and technologies for cooking, lighting and heating.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Health risks from household air pollution are particularly high among women and children, who tend to spend more time in and around cooking stoves.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Official development assistance for health has scaled up but with a major share spent on COVID-19.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: Total net official development assistance (ODA) for medical research and basic health sectors has significantly increased in recent years, primarily driven by the global response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: ODA for basic health care from all donors more than doubled in real terms between 2015 and 2022, rising from $10.5 billion to $21.1 billion (in constant 2022 prices).

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: It rose 4.4 per cent in 2022 compared to 2021.

id_argumento1: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages
id_argumento2: In 2022, COVID-19 control constituted the largest share of ODA for basic health care at 42 per cent, totalling $8.8 billion, of which $1.6 billion was for COVID-19 vaccine donations.
